event_info.what:
Hacker Olympics is a new, interactive spin on the basic hackathon. Hackers participate in a tournament, where diverse knowledge and skills help them to conquer a wide range of challenges. Accumulate points in a race to Hacker Olympics supremacy.

At 10:00pm, it’s pencils down and laptops closed. The Top 3 Teams will be awarded prizes and named Hacker Olympic Medalists!
event_info.how:
The Hacker Olympics is a fast-paced event where teams compete for five hours against each other to finish in the top 3 teams. Teams complete challenges to earn points, each of which make hackers think quickly, creatively and often outside their comfort zone.

Participate in teams of 4 - 6 people in front-end, back-end, or cross-discipline challenges. Knockout your competition with a red shell in the Mario Kart tournament. Use skills you didn’t know you had to reign victorious over the likes of Startup Charades, cryptography challenges, code puzzles, building of a meme generator, and more.

challenges.rules:
Each team must select 4 players and send one person each to a Wii station at their scheduled time.
 
The players will compete in a 10-minute Bomberman tournament. They will be awarded points based on ranked number of kills in each game.

If there is a tie, the tied teams will face off in a 1-kill match. The ranking in that match is the places they will get for score purposes.
challenges.scoring:
Scoring (per station):
1.     Most Kills: 25 points
2.     2nd Most: 15 points
3.     3rd most: 5 points
challenges.judges: Once your station’s game is finished, record the number of kills and corresponding team # for each of the 4 teams at your station.

challenges.rules:
Teams must pair up with another team so that at each Station so there are 2 teams competing against one another.
 
Charades is a game of pantomimes: you have to "act out" a phrase (in this case, a startup) without speaking, while the other members of your team try to guess what the phrase is. The objective is for your team to guess the phrase as quickly as possible.
 
Each team can choose 3 players who each get 2 minutes to act out as many clues as possible. While TEAM A is acting out clues TEAM B should be keeping time.
 
Game Play:
A player from TEAM A must draw a piece of paper from the Businessy Entrepreneurial Answer Receptacle (B.E.A.R) and act it out silently for the rest of his teammates. At the end of two minutes TEAM A should tally their correct answers and write it on the whiteboard.
 
As soon as TEAM A completes their first round, TEAM B should choose a player to act out clues. This should of course repeat until either: 3 players from each team has acted out clues.
challenges.scoring:
10 points per corect answer

25 point bonus to the winning team
challenges.judges: Record the team numbers and how many corresponding correct answers they got for each charades station.

challenges.rules:
6 teams compete at once. Each team gets 100 Cups. The objective is to stack cups as high as possible using only each other and the cups to create a structure that will stand tallest. No object other than cups can be part of the structure. No free-standing objects may be used to raise a hacker’s height to place cups higher up. People are a different story…
 
At the end of 10 minutes the team with the highest stack of cups will be named winner. The 2nd and 3rd highest stacks will also win points.

Special Case: If two (or more) teams are tied at the end of the 10 minutes a rapid-fire tie-breaking row must take place. The tied teams need to create a stack of single cups one on top of the previous, and the team with the highest single stack of cups is named winner. This team should receive a BONUS level to their official Stack Overflow score. So if two teams are tied with a level-count of 25 levels, the team who wins the tie-breaker will receive a bonus level to their score, making their final level-count 26.
challenges.scoring:
1.     1st place: 100 pts
2.     2nd Place: 70 pts
3.     3rd Place: 45 pts
challenges.judges: Count the levels of cups to determine who is the winner. Record the team number and level of cups in the score sheet for each of the 6 teams competing in this round.

challenges.rules:
You're an alien race attempting to save Earth from destruction.  You must race your spaceship across the world hitting all checkpoints, in sequence to diffuse the RedMatter explosives as fast as you can before detonation. Bend the world to your will to shrink the distance between you and the next checkpoint. Hectic 2 player fun.

Player 1: Uses Leap. Controls ship direction, hits all checkpoints.
Player 2: Uses Leap. Bends world, tries to minimize distance between Player 1 and the checkpoint.

Teams have 25 minutes to practice the controls and pick who participates in the challenge. Teams can tweak various settings such as the map projection and controls to optimize their play. These settings can be configured before the clock starts or during play by a 3rd player with a mouse.

Teams may change code to modify the interface directing the ship or rotating the globe. They may not increase the speed of the ship, change the size of maps, modify target positions, or disable existing features.

In the last 5 minutes, teams run a single time trial. The lowest time for the day is the winner of the challenge overall.
challenges.scoring:
100 points for finding all of the predetermined spots

50 points for revising the navigation code to make it faster to find each spot
challenges.judges: If a team navigates to all of the predetermined spots, they get 100 points. Record their time limit as well. If they revised the code to make it faster, give them 50 bonus points.

challenges.rules:
Build an application that can receive incoming emails with image attachments to {address}@{your team name}.asciiolympics.co using the SendGrid Parse API. Your application should respond with an ASCII representation of the image.

Bonus: Build an ASCII interface to read all of the e-mails received at this address. Image attachments in the ASCII interface should display in ASCII as well!
challenges.scoring:
100 points – For completing the main challenge

50 points – For completing the bonus challenge as well
challenges.judges: Have the team demo their application by sending an arbitrary image of your choice to the given address and verifying that the reply is an ASCII representation of the image. If they have participated in the bonus challenge, verify that they have created a purely text-based interface to read their e-mails in.

challenges.challengetitle: Catch Me If You Can - Google
challenges.rules:
You're Edward Snowden on the run. Plan your escape plan starting from Honolulu International Airport (HNL). Luckily, you have the power of BigQuery and a flights dataset at your disposal. So what's your plan? Avoid being on the ground as long as possible? Travel the longest distances? Travel to countries with no extradition agreements?
Deploy your application to App Engine. It should be able to calculate 3 potential escape routes with at least 4 destinations each.

Use the BigQuery dataset "airline_ontime_data.flights" in the dataset "bigquery-samples" for this challenge.
 
Bonus: Build a variable interface that lets the user select their variable “escape plan” – generate results based on their input. Example: rather than ONLY allowing the user to fly flights with the longest distance, let the user select if they prefer minimal ground time or longest flight time, etc.
challenges.scoring:
100 points – For completing the main challenge

50 points – For completing the bonus challenge as well
challenges.judges: Have the team demo their application to you, including the bonus challenge if they have chosen to complete it. Verify that it calculates 3 potential escape routes and that each one has 4 destinations.

challenges.rules:
Build an application where the user can provision a new Box account using their e-mail address. Upon completion of the provisioning, upload the following image to a new folder on their account: http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/dam/assets/130823121452-02-steve-ballmer-horizontal-gallery.jpg

Bonus: Build a Ballmer meme generator (with text on top and bottom inputted by user) that uses your newly created Box account as its data store.
challenges.scoring:
100 points for uploading the image to a newly provisioned Box account

50 points for generating a meme dynamically and uploading it to Box
challenges.judges: If their script uploads the static image to Box, they get 100 points. If the user can enter meme text (top and bottom of image), they get 50 bonus.

challenges.rules:
Build a user authentication system that utilizes no form fields or input fields. Your system must not accept a username or password from the user. Be creative and come up with a unique authentication system using alternative verification methods (ex. Voice verification, key-press detection, bluetooth , etc.)
 
Bonus: Use a Plantronics headset and their SDK as part of your authentication system. You get to keep your headset while supplies last if you successfully complete this bonus challenge!
challenges.scoring:
100 points – For completing the main challenge

100 points – For completing the bonus challenge as well
challenges.judges: Have the team demo their application to you, including the bonus challenge if they have chosen to complete it. If they have done the bonus challenge successfully, they get to keep their headset.

challenges.rules: Create a new Atlassian Bitbucket git repo. Give each of your team members access to it. One of your team members should create the first portion of an application that utilizes the Hacker Olympics leaderboard.json API. Each of your team members must then create their own branch of the application on Bitbucket and merge their code via a Pull Request.
challenges.judges: Have the team demo their app, confirm that all team members have branched and committed to the project and that theyr'e using the leaderboard json.

challenges.rules: Go to http://thehackerolympics.com/phonenumbers.html to find a comma-delimited list of phone numbers, Use the WhitePages Phone Number Lookup API to find the correlation between all of these numbers. There may be multiple correct answers to this challenge! You will need to use your powers of observation (not just your elite hacker skills) to solve this one.
challenges.scoring:
100 points for finding one of the correct correlations (LIST HERE)

50 points for creativity
challenges.judges:
If a team finds one of the following correlations, they receive 100 points:

If they find an unusual correlation (like that each word has “Cat” in it or something we did not expect) they get 50 bonus points (they cannot get multiple bonuses for the same challenge).

challenges.rules: Check out an Arduino Uno and a USB cable from the registration desk. Use the Twilio <Sms> API and your Arduino in order to build a system that receives incoming SMS messages and blinks them out in Morse code on your Arduino using the built-in LED.
challenges.scoring: 200 points – For completing the main challenge
challenges.judges: Have the team demo their application to you. Try sending a sample message to their application to verify that it works.

challenges.rules:
Build a code-powered Rube Goldberg chain reaction machine that begins and ends with a Parse API. The data must stay intact throughout the chain! You must transfer the following JSON object through the entire chain intact: {'data':'TwilioCon', 'foo': {'bar':'baz'}}
Example: Enter data in a web form which POSTs to Parse. Parse fires off an SMS with the user’s input which is received by another Twilio phone number, and is then sent via e-mail to an address that is based on Sendgrid, which then sends the data back to Parse to be stored in a database. Be as creative as possible!
challenges.scoring: 20 points per unique API that is part of the successful chain (API, webhook, etc.)
challenges.judges: Have the team demo their application to you, and show you how each part of the chain works. The team will get 10 points for each link in the chain once it has been proven to work successfully.

challenges.rules: Go to http://thehackerolympics.com/songsascode.html - here you will find a list of code snippets that each represent a song. Guess what song each snippet represents and write down your answers. Call over a judge to verify them and submit your score!
challenges.judges: Confirm each answer with the master list in the judging app, give the team 10 points * the number of correct answers they go. They should only submit their answers once for this challenge!
challenges.resourcetitle: Hacker Olympics Songs as Code List

challenges.rules: Set up an AWS instance. On that instance, write a script in your language of choice that has a runtime of as close to 42 seconds as possible as determined by the `time` command. You may not use any time-based delays or waits to achieve this runtime. You may achieve the runtime through inefficient code, unwise server configurations, or any other creative means.
challenges.scoring:
100 points for writing a script that is within a +/- 5 second runtime of 42 seconds

50 bonus points for hitting between a +/- 500ms runtime of 42 seconds
challenges.judges: Have them run their script with the `time` command (ex. time ruby app.rb), if it is 42 exactly they get 150 points, if it is between 37 and 47 seconds they get 100 points. Also confirm that it is running on an AWS instance and that they did not use any time-based delays.

challenges.rules: We love lists and animated GIFs almost as much as Buzzfeed and tumblr.  Craft a web-based animated GIF generator on a Windows Azure Web Site, Cloud Service, or VM so that it can be shared with the world.
challenges.scoring: 100 points for creating an animated gif generator that stores on Azure
challenges.judges: Generator a GIF using their app and verify that it uploads to Azure

rules.rule: 15 minutes before TwilioCon Hacker Olympics begins, we will publish a list of challenges. Other than the Required Challenges, which you must complete, you may choose to complete as many or as few challenges as you wish.
For each challenge that your team completes the team will receive a fixed or variable amount of points depending on the points allotted for completion of the challenge.
Different hackers on the same team may be completing different challenges. So be sure to delegate well as a team!

When you believe your team has completed a challenge, simply wave the light stick at your table. This will alert a judge to come check your work. If they deem the challenge completed your team will receive points.

Startup Charades, Stack Overflow and Bombs Away! are three challenges that are extra special. In order for every team to participate, these challenges are scheduled by Team Number. To see what time slot your Team is scheduled to compete in a Required Challenge, visit the schedule.
If you finish all available challenges, check the rules and attempt to get the bonus points for every challenge that has bonus points.

You must form teams of 4-6 people (ideally teams will consist of 6 people). Once you have formed a team, choose a table. Your team name and number will be on the table. It is very important you memorize your Team Number, as the points your team earns will be tracked by your Team Number.
Due to space we are capping the number of teams to 80. Some smaller teams might be forced to disband and join other teams, until we have less than 80 teams.
No Larping. Even if you have a lightsaber from last years Hacker Olympics. Larping kills.
When a team (or hacker from a specific team) completes a challenge, Points will be added to your Team Number
You can follow the rank of your team on the Leaderboard.

Some challenges are worth a fixed number of points. Other challenges are scored on a tier, where the team will be awarded points according to their placement. (Example: 1st Place: 100 pts, 2nd Place: 50 pts, 3rd Place: 25 pts).
